statement.tex:
%text If the radius of a sphere is measured as
$R=9$ cm with an error of $\Delta R=0.03$ cm, then find the approximate error in calculating its surface area $(S)$ %

options.tex: If $\Delta S$ be the error in calculating the surface area, then \[ \qquad \Delta S = \frac{dS}{dR}\cdot \Delta R \]
If $\Delta S$ be the error in calculating the surface area, then \[ \qquad \Delta S = \frac{dS}{dR}\]

reason.tex:
$\dfrac{dS}{dR}$ is the rate of change of the surface area with respect to the radius\newline
But the actual change (or error in this case) would be \[ \qquad \Delta S = \frac{dS}{dR}\times \Delta R \]
